text: Frederick Albert McDonald (c. 1872? April 1926) was an Australian politician and possible murder victim. McDonald studied at the University of Sydney. He became a teacher, and rose to become President of the Teachers Federation of New South Wales. In 1922 he stood for election to the Australian House of Representatives, and won the new seat of Barton for the Labor Party. His main opponent was Hector Lamond, who had been the Nationalist member for the abolished seat of Illawarra. ==Disappearance== In the 1925 election, McDonald was narrowly defeated by Nationalist candidate Thomas Ley. McDonald took the result to court, claiming that Ley had tried to bribe him, asking him not to put in his nomination papers.The common touch of politics: The common touch of politics, accessdate: August 1, 2016 However, on 15 April 1926 McDonald disappeared on his way to a meeting with New South Wales Premier Jack Lang. They were planning to have the election result declared void.Australian Dictionary of Biography: Thomas John Ley. Retrieved 19 June 2015 Neither McDonald's body nor his brief case were ever found. Thomas Ley was found guilty of murder in England, but it was decided he was insane. He was sent to Broadmoor Hospital, where he died. It is believed that Ley was responsible for McDonald's disappearance. He is also suspected of being involved in the suspicious deaths of other of his political opponents. ==Related pages== *List of people who disappeared mysteriously: 1910â€“1990 ==References== Category:Missing people Category:Members of the Australian House of Representatives Category:Year of death unknown
title: Frederick McDonald
